Fig. 1 XRD patterns of (a) FCMA-LDH and the derived catalysts promoted with Pd, Pt or Rh, (b) Calcined LDO. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectra of (a) FCMA-LDH and its promoted forms with Pd, Pt or Rh; (b) Calcined LDO. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FT-IR spectra of FCMA-LDH and the Pd, Pt or Rh promoted catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TGA curves of FCMA-LDH and the promoted catalyst with Pd, Pt or Rh. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of calcined FCMA-LDO and the Pd, Pt or Rh promoted catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM images of calcined catalyst sample. (a) FCMA-LDH, (b) FCMA-LDO, (C) Pd/FCMA-LDH, (d) Pd/FCMA-LDO, (e) Pt/FCMA-LDH, (f) Pt/FCMA-LDO, (g) Rh/FCMA-LDH, (h) Rh/FCMA-LDO. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption curves, (b) Pore size distributions of calcined FCMA-LDO and the promoted catalyst with Pd, Pt or Rh. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS full survey (a), Fe 2p (b), and Cu 2p(c), O 1 s(d) of calcined FCMA-LDO and the promoted catalyst with Pd, Pt or Rh. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Reaction analysis of catalysts. (a) CO conversion, (b) CO2 selectivity, (c) CH4 selectivity, (d) C2+H selectivity, (e) R-OH selectivity, (f) alcohols distribution among total alcohols. College of New Materials and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology 19 Qing-Yuan North Road Beijing 102617 China A highly dispersed FeCu/LDH-based catalyst precursor was prepared by co-precipitation method, and the catalysts promoted with Pd, Pt or Rh were then prepared using an equal-volume impregnation method to be used in syngas-to-alcohol reaction. These samples were characterized by XRD, Raman, FT-IR, In-situ DRIFT, XPS, SEM and N2 adsorption desorption. The study reveals that the 2D nanosheet structure of the LDH precursor has a large surface area and evenly distributed active sites, leading to the superior catalyst performance. The promoted catalyst generated even higher catalytic activity and alcohol selectivity, notably reducing undesired methane and CO2 by-products. Rh incorporation obviously enhanced the thermal stability of the catalyst, leading to the long-term retention of the LDH structure. Rich -OH groups offer surface basicity, thereby significantly enhancing its catalytic performance to lower the CO2 selectivity to 1.34 % and methane to 1.67 % while achieving a remarkable alcohol selectivity of 95.1 %. In-situ DRIFT results reveal that Rh promotion helps balance the gaseous adsorption and bridge adsorption of CO for improved overall syngas-to-alcohols reaction results. Graphical Abstract Keywords Syngas conversion FeCu/LDH catalyst CO hydrogenation Noble metal promoters Syngas-to-alcohols Data availability The authors can provide the data upon request. 1 Introduction Syngas conversion reaction has emerged as a significant research focus in energy and chemical engineering due to its potential for utilizing any carbon-bearing materials into fuels and chemical feedstocks [1–3]. Syngas are primarily derived from coal or biomass gasification, natural gas reforming [4]. Limited petroleum resources and increasing greenhouse gas emission becomes more urgent issues, thus direct synthesis of alcohols from syngas can offer a promising solution to the crisis. Furthermore, since elements such as S, N and Hg are normally removed in syngas production, downstream products are virtually free of these contaminants [5,6]. Consequently, efficient conversion of syngas into alcohols using catalysts not only mitigates the shortage of chemical raw materials but also provides a clean fuel additive. Alcohols compounds are extensively used in various process industries, such as food processing, pharmaceuticals and semiconductor sectors. Catalysts are pivotal in the synthesis of alcohols from syngas, which involves complex side reactions. Therefore, designing catalysts with high conversion rates and selectivities presents significant challenges. Over the past few decades, alcohols synthesis from syngas catalysts have undergone numerous improvements, focusing on the optimization of the catalyst composition, CO conversion, alcohol yields and selectivities [7–11]. In alcohol synthesis reaction, CO undergoes dissociative adsorption on the catalyst surface, breaking the carbon-oxygen bond. Subsequent hydrogenation of the adsorbed carbon and coupling of alkyl groups leads to the formation of hydrocarbon products, which are characteristic of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts [12]. Conversely, CO can bind and associatively adsorb on the catalyst surface and then undergoes hydrogenation to produce methanol, a process characteristic of methanol synthesis (MS) catalysts [13]. Most single-active-center catalysts support only one form of CO adsorption, thus exhibiting high selectivity for either hydrocarbons or methanol. However, the formation mechanism of higher alcohols (HA) involves both types of reactions, necessitating a bifunctional catalyst that supports both dissociative and non-dissociative adsorption of CO. For FeCu-based catalysts, the nature of active sites has been extensively studied [14–17], with Fe used for dissociative adsorption of CO to generate alkyl chains and Cu for non-dissociative adsorption of CO [18]. FeCu-based syngas-to-alcohols catalyst is active, low cost and rich in natural resource. In 2013, Bao et al. [19] synthesized an Fe-Cu catalyst via the impregnation method for higher alcohol synthesis (HAS). Their results demonstrated that the catalyst achieved high HAS catalytic activity and low methane selectivity at elevated Cu/Fe ratios. Additionally, increased reaction temperature intensified the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, indirectly confirming the high WGS activity of Cu active centers. To elucidate the active phase of Fe-Cu catalysts, Lu et al. [20] investigated ordered macroporous Fe-Cu systems, revealing that dual active sites, i.e., high density uniformly distributed defective Cu0 and Fe5C2 nanoparticles, favored higher alcohol formation. To enhance the dispersibility and structural order of Fe and Cu, Han [21] and Tae Wan Kim et al. [22] developed highly dispersed Fe-Cu catalysts using co-precipitation and citrate complexation methods separately. The former leveraged the hydrotalcite structure of layered double hydroxides (LDH), achieving a catalyst with 20.77 % total alcohol selectivity, half of the alcohol is ethanol. The latter incorporated bimetallic Fe-Cu component into the perovskite frameworks, yielding a catalyst with 95 % C2+ alcohol selectivity. Li et al. [23] synthesized CuxFeyMg4-LDH precursors with Cu/Fe molar ratios of 1:1, 2:1, 4:1, and 6:1 via nucleation and aging process. This catalyst demonstrated exceptional long-chain alcohol selectivity under mild conditions (1.0 MPa, 250°C). Through topological transformation (calcination at 500°C for 4 h) and two-step activation, i.e., the first step at 300°C for 2 h in 25 % CO, 25 % H2 and 50 % CO2 gas mixture, followed by another activation step at 350°C for 1 h. Fe5C2 nanoclusters were formed on Cu nanoparticle surfaces, achieving 29.8 % total alcohol selectivity, 89.9 % higher alcohol selectivity, and a space-time yield (STY) of 0.101 g·h−1, proving a high-performance catalyst. In general, FeCu-based catalysts exhibited higher selectivity of C2+ alcohols compared to Rh-based, Mo-based and modified methanol catalysts, while promoted catalysts demonstrated higher CO conversion and total alcohol selectivity [18] Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are 2d material composed of positively charged metal hydroxide layers and negatively charged anion layer. Their structural formula is [M2+ 1-xM3+ x(OH)2] (An-)x/n·mH2O, where M3+ and M2+ represent trivalent and divalent metal cations, An- represents interlayer anions, and x ranges from 0.2 to 0.4 to form LDHs with good crystallinity. The adjustability and dispersibility of LDH layer metal ions facilitate the introduction of multiple metal elements and enhance their synergistic effects. The topological transformation of LDHs into metal oxides or metal-metal oxide composites upon calcining is significant for the synthesis of dual-active or multi-active-centers of the catalyst in the syngas-to-alcohols reaction [24]. To improve the CO conversion and the alcohol selectivity, FeCu-based catalysts was designed and synthesized using LDH as a precursor, incorporating Pt, Pb, and Rh as metal promoters to investigate alcohols synthesis from syngas. To understand the effects of different noble metal promoters on catalyst structure and performance, various characterization techniques was employed, such as XRD, Raman, FT-IR, In-situ DRIFT, XPS, SEM, and N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. Through these analyses, the relationship between the physicochemical properties of the FeCu-LDH-based catalysts and their catalytic performance were scientifically explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials RhCl3·3 H2O was purchased from Beijing Innochem Technology Co., Ltd., Pd(NO3)2·2 H2O was from Energy Chemical, and Pt(NO3)2 was from Shanghai Boer Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Mg(NO3)2·H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, and anhydrous Na2CO3 were all purchased from Aladdin, while NaOH was obtained from Beijing Chemical Works. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The preparation of catalysts involves a co-precipitation method. Two solutions are prepared in the following steps. The first one was prepared by dissolving 2.828 g Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (0.07 mol·L−1), 5.0736 g Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (0.21 mol·L−1), 3.5897 g Mg(NO3)2·H2O (0.14 mol·L−1), and 5.2518 g Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (0.14 mol·L−1) in 100 mL of deionized water to obtain the solution “A”. Then dissolve 3.584 g NaOH and 4.452 g Na2CO3 in 100 mL of deionized water to prepare solution “B”, where [NaOH] = 1.6[M2+ + M3+] and [CO3 2-] = 2.0[M3+]. In a beaker containing 50 mL of DI water, Solutions A and B were dripped into the beaker simultaneously while vigorously stirring at room temperature and at pH 10.0. The resulted slurry is stirred for 30 minutes at room temperature and then aged in an autoclave at 60°C for 24 h. After filtration, the slurry is washed with distilled water until the filtrate becomes neutral and finally dried at 60°C for 12 h to obtain the sample FCMA-LDH. Subsequently, the noble metal Pd, Pt or Rh promoters were added to promote the FCMA-LDH catalyst using the equal-volume impregnation method, with each promoter loaded at 0.1 wt% relative to the catalyst precursor. The impregnated samples were dried at 60°C for 12 h to obtain M/FCMA-LDH (where M = Pd, Pt or Rh). These catalysts were calcined in an air atmosphere at a heating rate of 3°C·min−1 until reaching 600°C, maintained for 6 h. The resulting catalysts were denoted as FCMA-LDO and M/FCMA-LDO, where M represents the metals Pd, Pt or Rh. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The phase structure of the catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). patterns of the samples were recorded by a D/max-2600 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation as the source, the emitter power was set at 9 kW, and the scanning was conducted within a range of 5–80° at a scanning speed of 4°·min−1. Raman spectra patterns of the samples were recorded by Renishaw in Via Raman spectrometer equipped with a laser at λ= 532 nm and a power of 45 W. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed using a Tensor II infrared spectrometer. A small amount of sample was mixed uniformly with KBr powder and pressed into a transparent disk using a tablet press for FT-IR measurement. The wavenumber range was set from 4000 to 400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was tested using a TG209F3 instrument from Netzsch, Germany. The temperature range for sample testing was from 30 to 800°C under an air atmosphere. The heating ramp was set at 3°C·min−1 and maintained at 100°C, 300°C and 600°C each for 1 h in the TGA test. H2 Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted using an AutoChem1 II 2920 temperature-programmed chemical adsorption analyzer. A 50 mg catalyst sample was pretreated under high-purity Ar atmosphere (30 sccm) at 300°C for 1 h, then cooled to 50°C, and switched to a mixed gas of H2/Ar = 1/9 (30 sccm) for temperature-programmed reduction. The temperature was increased to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C·min−1 and held for 30 minutes, with the consumption of H2 detected by TCD. XPS analysis was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer. A survey scan was done with a pass energy of 150 eV and a step size of 1 eV, while high-resolution scans used a pass energy of 50 eV at a step size of 0.1 eV. The binding energy was calibrated to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. In-situ DRIFTS measurements were conducted using a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer. The sample (50 mg) was loaded into an infrared cell with quartz wool to retain the catalyst during purging. After a 10-minute N2 purge, the catalyst was reduced with 10 mL·min−1 hydrogen heating at 3°C·min−1 to 350°C for 3 h. The sample was then cooled to room temperature and exposed to 10 mL·min−1 N2 before heating to 300°C at 3°C·min−1. The gas was switched to a H2/CO/N2 (8/4/1) mixture, and infrared spectra were recorded at various reaction times. N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were performed using an ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88 physical adsorption analyzer. Before testing, the oxidized samples were vacuum-dried at 300°C for 4 h. During testing, the samples were cooled to −196°C in liquid nitrogen for N2 adsorption-desorption experiments. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method, and the pore structure of the samples was determined according to the BJH model. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation A 1 g sample of the catalyst, diluted with 3 mL of 100-mesh quartz particles, was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor at 250°C, 3.0 MPa, with a Gas Hourly Space Velocity (WHSV) of 3600 mL·gcat -¹ ·h-¹ , and a H2/CO ratio of 2:1. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced under a hydrogen atmosphere of 3600 mL·h-¹ at 250°C and atmospheric pressure for 8 h. After reduction, the temperature was lowered to 100°C, and the reactor was switched to Gas Chromatography (GC) to analyze gas-phase and liquid-phase products. The liquid-phase products included water, methanol, and other alcohol products. The syngas, with a H2/CO volume ratio of 2.0, was adjusted to the required pressure for the reaction, and the temperature was increased to the reaction temperature to initiate the Hydrogenation of CO to alcohols synthesis reaction. The raw feed gas and products were initially passed through a hot trap (150°C) which retained heavy products like waxes. They were then condensed in a cold trap (1.5°C) where mainly oils and water were collected. Finally, the gas was introduced into an Agilent gas chromatograph for real-time reaction analysis. The selectivity of the products was calculated using the external standard method. The gas-phase products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph equipped with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). The liquid-phase products were analyzed offline using a gas chromatograph equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and an Agilent INNOWAX column. The selectivity of short-chain hydrocarbons (C1-C4) in the gas-phase products was calculated using the external standard method. The calculation methods for CO conversion and product selectivity are as follows: Xco = F in C in , CO − F out C out , CO F in C in , CO × 100 % S CO 2 = F out C out , CO 2 F in C in , CO − F out C out , CO × 100 % S Hyd = ∑ ni F out C i F in C in , CO − F out C out , CO × 100 % S Alc = 1 − S Hyd − S CO 2 In the Formulas mentioned above, the terms have the following meanings: X co represents the CO conversion rate; F in stands for the inlet gas flow rate; C in , CO denotes the initial concentration of CO in the inlet gas; F out represents the outlet gas flow rate; C out , CO denotes the concentration of CO in the outlet gas; S CO 2 represents the selectivity of CO2; C i stands for the carbon number of product i; ni denotes the number of carbon atoms per molecule of product i; S Hyd represents the selectivity of hydrocarbon products; and S Alc represents the selectivity of alcohol products. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The crystalline structure of all samples was examined by XRD. As depicted in Fig. 1(a), all samples exhibited distinct characteristics of LDHs prior to calcination. These peaks corresponded to well-defined lattice planes, including (003), (006), (009), (015), (018), (110), and (113), observed at approximately 11.6°, 23.5°, 34.8°, 39.3°, 46.7°, 60.3°, and 61.7°, respectively. The peaks were symmetric and sharp, reflecting the ordered structure of the LDHs. All the reflective characteristic peaks of well-crystallized LDH were detected, indicating that Mg²⁺ in the LDH layers was substituted by Cu²⁺. This substitution is attributed to the similar ionic radii of Cu²⁺ (0.73 Å) and Mg²⁺ (0.72 Å). The crystal structure parameters are shown in Figure Table S1 and the interplanar spacing between the (003) and (110) crystallographic planes of the LDH was determined using Bragg’s law. The unit cell parameter ‘a’ represents the mean distance between adjacent metal cations within the LDH layer, while ‘c’ denotes the interlayer spacing parameter. Upon loading with Pd, Pt or Rh, the inter-cation distances within the layer remained unchanged, whereas the interlayer spacing increased to different extents [25]. Indicating successful loading of promotional metal to LDH. This offset resulted in a decrease in D110 from 9.00 nm for the pure LDH precursor material to 6.83 nm, 7.45 nm, 8.04 nm, indicating a reduction in LDHs layer thickness [26]. The diffraction intensities of the (110) and (113) peaks showed little difference among all samples, suggesting that the addition of metal additives did not cause significant changes in the crystal structure of FeCuMgAl-LDH [27]. This may be due to the low content (0.1 wt%) of the metal additives. After calcination, the unpromoted FCMA-LDO catalyst exhibited clear diffraction peaks of Fe2O3, Fe3O4, Fe2CuO4, CuO and MgO, indicating the conversion of LDH to Mixed Metal Oxide (MMO) as shown in Fig. 1(b). All catalysts after calcination didn’t showed any peak of Al oxide, indicating that Al is highly dispersed in LDO [21]. It is evident that the diffraction peak intensities of Fe2CuO4 (∼36.0°) and CuO (∼38.5°) are significantly higher in the Rh-loaded samples compared to the unpromoted and Pd/Pt promoted samples. Enhanced crystallization of Fe₂CuO₄ and CuO during calcination can be attributed to Rh, which promotes these phases via electronic effects and heterogeneous nucleation mechanisms [28–30]. The peaks of Pt/FCMA-LDO and Pd/FCMA-LDO are higher than those of the unsupported FCMA-LDO catalyst, it’s indicating that Pd, Pt or Rh are beneficial for strengthening the interactive effect of Cu and Fe particles, and the exposed grain size is larger, which is conducive to the progress of the reaction [31]. Interestingly, the M/FCMA-LDO catalyst promoted with Rh after calcination still retains some diffraction peaks of LDH crystal planes, indicating that the thermal stability of the precursor is enhanced after Rh loading [32–34]. With calcination, an intriguing variation in the degree of structural collapse was observed from the catalysts. Notably, the layered architectures of FCMA-LDO, Pd/FCMA-LDO and Pt/FCMA-LDO catalysts underwent near-complete disintegration. In contrast, the Rh/FCMA-LDO catalyst managed to preserve a portion of its original layered structure. The remaining LDH structures are rich in hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surfaces, which modulate the alkalinity of the catalyst surface and potentially enhance its catalytic performance [35–37]. This result is also consistent with the SEM analysis and may have a positive impact on the performance of the catalyst. The three characteristic peaks related to LDH in Raman spectra as shown in Fig. 2(a). Among them, the bands within the fingerprint region at 546 cm−1 and 706 cm−1 are attributed to the lattice stretching vibrations between metal and oxygen atoms. The band located at 1060 cm−1 corresponds to the ν₁ mode of CO3 2- [38], indicating that the interlayer anions in LDH are CO3 2-, which is consistent with the results obtained from infrared spectroscopy. The Raman patterns after calcination is shown in Fig. 2(b), where 292 cm-¹ , 345 cm−1 and 683 cm−1 corresponds to the A1 g, B1 g and B2 g mode of Cu-O [39], and 586 cm−1 and 1130 cm−1 represent two different vibrations of Fe-O(Fe2+, Fe3+) [40,41]. Interestingly, the vibration intensity of Cu-O increases after loading Rh, while the intensity of Fe-O decreases. Additionally, the peak at 619 cm−1 experiences a red shift, which may be due to the residual LDH structure. The FT-IR spectra in Fig. 3 indicate the broad absorption bands of the LDH precursor at 3437 cm−1 and 1631 cm−1 correspond to the stretching and bending vibrations of O-H of the hydrotalcite layer and interlayer water molecules [42,43]. Due to the presence of interlayer carbonates in LDH, the absorption band at 1368 cm−1 can be attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of C-O [44,45]. In addition, the absorption bands between 600 and 1100 cm−1 in LDH are attributed to the metal-oxygen-metal (M-O-M) and oxygen-metal-oxygen (O-M-O) stretching vibrations in metal oxides [46–48]. Thermal stability of all the synthesized samples was confirmed by TGA data, as shown in Fig. 4. All samples undergo three stages of weight loss. The first stage occurs around 50°C to 350°C, corresponding to the removal of physically adsorbed water and interlayer water molecules in LDH. The second stage occurs around 350°C to 600°C, corresponding to the dehydroxylation of the LDH lamellae. The third stage occurs around 600°C to 800°C, corresponding to the decomposition of interlayer anions in LDH [49–52]. In the second stage, LDH precursors with and without Pd and Pt loading showed significant mass loss at ∼400 and ∼550°C, while Rh/FCMA-LDH had a smaller mass loss, indicating enhanced thermal stability with promoted Rh, which corresponds to the characterization results of XRD. The incorporation of Rh additives facilitates desorption and decomposition processes at lower temperatures, while at higher calcination temperatures, these additives stabilize the layered structure, thereby retarding decomposition. The H2-TPR profiles, as shown in Fig. 5, illustrate the reduction behavior of the FCMA-LDH and M/FCMA-LDH samples after calcination. Two reduction processes are observed at low temperature (60–300°C) and high temperature (>300°C). For the FCMA-LDO catalyst, the first prominent peak corresponds to the reduction of CuO to metallic Cu, while the subsequent shoulder peak is attributed to the reduction of either CuFe2O4 to metallic Cu and Fe3O4 or CuAl2O4 to metallic Cu and Al2O3. For the remaining three samples, there is only one intense reduction peak in the low temperature region. The intense reduction peaks in the low-temperature region are due to the reduction of CuFe2O4 to metallic copper [53]. All samples have a broad reduction peak in the high temperature region. The peaks observed in the high temperature region for all samples may be due to the continuous reduction of iron oxides to metallic iron via an FeO intermediate [54–56]. The Cu reduction temperatures of the FCMA-LDH catalysts promoted with Pd, Pt or Rh all increase, which may be due to the enhanced interactive effect between Fe and Cu after loading with noble metals. In the high temperature region, Pd and Pt exhibit strong H2 dissociation and activation capabilities [28]. The dissociated hydrogen follows the hydrogen spillover effect on Cu atoms, promoting the reduction of iron oxides and thus lowering their reduction temperatures. H2-TPR provides direct evidence that the promoted catalyst Fe is in close contact with Cu, enhancing the interactive effect between Fe and Cu. To study the morphological characteristics of the catalyst surface, SEM characterization was performed as shown in Fig. 6. The LDH precursors Fig. 6(a, c, e, g) were successfully synthesized and exhibited a very distinct layered structure. While Fig. 6(b, d, f, h), all catalysts experienced structural collapse, with the most severe collapse occurring before loading. However, after loading Rh, a part of the layered structure was still retained, which is consistent with the XRD, TGA, H2-TPR characterization results. Furthermore, Figure S1 displays the EDX mapping of Fe, Cu, Mg and Al elements in the FCMA-LDO and Pd/FCMA-LDO, Pt/FCMA-LDO, Rh/FCMA-LDO catalysts and their precursor, revealing the uniform distribution of Fe and Cu elements in the catalyst and precursor, which is attributed to the topological mapping of LDH. To investigate the textural properties of LDO catalysts, physical adsorption-desorption characterization was performed on LDO-based samples, as illustrated in Fig. 7(a). All samples exhibited Type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicate the presence of large mesopores and slit-like irregular pore structures within the solids. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the catalyst does indeed contain a large number of mesopores. In Table 1, The specific surface area of Pt/FCMA-LDO decreased significantly compared to its unpromoted precursor. This phenomenon may be attributed to the blockage of catalyst pores and strong acid of the impregnation solution during the process. An experiment was designed to verify the acidic effect of the impregnation solution as depicted in the Figure S2 and Table S2. The chemical state of FeCu elements in the supported catalyst before and after loading was studied by XPS. As illustrated in Fig. 8(a), the XPS survey spectra confirmed the presence of Fe, Cu, Mg, and Al elements in all catalysts, but no Pd, Pt or Rh was found in the M/FCMA-LDO catalyst, possibly due to the low loading amount (0.1 % wt). Fig. 8(b) and Table S3 demonstrates that, the binding energies for the Fe2+ species are observed at approximately 711.3 eV for the Fe 2p3/2 orbital and 724.5 eV for the Fe 2p1/2 orbital. For the Fe3+ species, the binding energies are located at around 714.2 eV for the Fe 2p3/2 orbital and 727.4 eV for the Fe 2p1/2 orbital. Additionally, the spectrum exhibits four distinct satellite peaks in 718.0, 731.5, 720.8 and 735.0 eV. These satellite peaks are indicative of the presence of multiple oxidation states and the complex electronic structure of iron in the sample. Fe exists in the form of Fe2+ and Fe3+ in the catalyst, and there are four satellite peaks in the Fe XPS spectrum. This is due to the high spin state of Fe2+, indicating that the iron in the catalyst exists in the form of Fe2O3, Fe3O4, or alloy, because pure Fe3O4 does not have satellite peaks[57,58], which corresponds to the XRD spectra data. The binding energies of the 2p3/2 orbital levels of Fe3+ and Fe2+ increased after loading, indicating that the promoted metal interacted with Fe. As can be seen from Fig. 8(c) and Table S4, two prominent satellite peaks are observed at approximately 962.3 and 941.4 eV plus 944.0 eV. Since 944.0 eV is a strong satellite peak, two peaks at 941.4 and 944.0 eV can be clearly fitted. These satellite peaks are indicative of the presence of CuO or a copper alloy within the catalyst. The peak at 934.4 eV is attributed to the Cu2+ 2p3/2 binding energy, while the peak at 954.3 eV corresponds to the Cu2+ 2p1/2 binding energy. Fig. 8(d) and Table S5 reveals the two distinct peaks at 531.8 and 530.1 eV, which are assigned to adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, respectively. Adsorbed oxygen, resulting from the adsorption of hydroxyl groups or defect oxygen due to surface oxygen on oxygen vacancies, is indicative of surface-active sites. The ratio of these two types of oxygen species can be used to quantitatively determine the oxygen vacancy content in the catalyst. The introduction of Pd and Rh increases the oxygen vacancy content, which in turn enhances the catalytic performance. Conversely, the decrease in oxygen vacancy content can be observed after Pt loading, which may be associated with a substantial reduction in the specific surface area of the catalyst. Consequently, it can be anticipated that Pt promoted catalysts will exhibit inferior performance than the Rh and Pd-promoted counterparts. 3.2 Catalyst performance 3.2.1 Evaluation of catalyst activity Under the reaction conditions of 250°C, 3.0 MPa, H2/CO = 2, and WHSV = 3600 mL·gcat -¹ ·h-¹ , an evaluation reaction was carried out to prepare alcohols from syngas gas, and the catalytic performance of FCMA-LDO catalyst was studied with different precious metal additives Pd, Pt or Rh. Fig. 9(a) shows the line graph of CO conversion rate as a function of reaction time. From Table 2, it can be seen that the CO conversion rate and total alcohol selectivity of the catalyst promoted with precious metals have been improved to varying degrees, indicating that the addition of precious metals enhances the catalytic activity. Fe-Cu is highly dispersed in the unpromoted FCMA-LDO catalyst, but poor CO hydrogenation activity and synergistic effect are resulted from this sample. The CO conversion rate is 11.95 %, the total alcohol selectivity is 60.43 %, and it has high water vapor shift activity with a CO2 selectivity of 25.03 %. Fig. 9(b-f) show that the performance of the promoted catalyst has been improved to varying degrees. For Pd/FCMA-LDO, Pd can enhance the H2 dissociation activity of the Fe-Cu catalyst[28]. The increase in CO conversion rate and total alcohol selectivity can be attributed to the preferential deposition of Pd on Fe, and on the surface of catalysts promoted with a small amount of Pd. CO can also preferentially adsorb on Pd, enhancing the non-dissociation adsorption of CO and weakening the dissociation adsorption [59]. For Pt/FCMA-LDO, it can be attributed to the strong H2 dissociation activity of Pt. While Rh/FCMA-LDO significantly increased CO conversion rate (49.0 %) and total alcohol selectivity (95.1 %), the selectivity of C2+ alcohols also slightly improved. Interestingly, Rh/FCMA-LDO greatly reduced the water gas shift reaction, and the CO₂ selectivity decreased to a surprisingly 1.34 %. This phenomenon may be attributed to the preserved LDH structure within the Rh/FCMA-LDO catalyst following calcination, which provides the catalyst basicity and oxygen vacancies. From the Table S7, it can be seen that the performance of promoted catalysts in recent years is excellent. H2-TPR data suggest that adding three precious metals improves the interactive effect between Fe and Cu. In the case of Rh/FCMA-LDO, the reduction of Fe-Cu requires higher temperatures, demonstrating enhanced interactive ability and superior catalytic performance. Additionally, XRD and SEM data indicate that larger particles facilitate the hydrogenation of CO and promote hydrogen formylation reactions. 3.2.2 Catalyst stability evaluation Repeated stability experiments were conducted for the Rh-supported catalyst, designated as Rh/FCMA-LDO-Re. Figure S2 and Table S6 present the results of a 200 h continuous reaction over the Rh/FCMA-LDO catalyst. The results demonstrate that the catalyst exhibited excellent stability following a short induction period within the first 20 hours. 3.3 Mechanistic studies on CO hydrogenation To elucidate the intermediates and types of CO adsorption during the reaction over FeCu/LDH catalysts, in-situ characterization was performed for FCMA-LDO and Rh/FCMA-LDO under a synthesis gas atmosphere (H2/CO/N2 = 8/4/1). Fig. 10(a-f) depicts the in-situ DRIFTS absorption spectra of the FCMA-LDO catalyst over a 100-minute reaction period. The spectra reveal that FCMA-LDO and Rh/FCMA-LDO exhibit similar absorption peaks, suggesting a common reaction pathway for CO hydrogenation to alcohols on these catalysts. The distinction lies in the intensity of the absorption peaks for HCOO* , H3CO* and gaseous methane. Peaks in the range of 2240–2060 cm−1 are attributed to the vibration of gaseous CO, while those in the range of 2000–1900 cm−1 and 1180–1710 cm−1 correspond to bridged and multiply bonded CO adsorption on metal sites, respectively [60–62]. The intensity of the bridged and multiply bonded CO adsorption peaks, as well as the CH4 peak, is stronger on FCMA-LDO than on Rh/FCMA-LDO. This indicates that the FCMA-LDO catalyst has a greater propensity to convert CO into CH4 and other hydrocarbons, whereas the Rh/FCMA-LDO catalyst tends to inhibit the formation of hydrocarbon compounds, in agreement with the reaction test findings. Both samples exhibit characteristic peaks around 1630–1610 cm−1, 1376 cm−1 and 2800–2730 cm−1, with a distinct peak at 2680 cm−1, signifying the presence of the HCOO* intermediate [61]. HCOO* is a crucial intermediate in syngas conversion to alcohols, which can be hydrogenated to form H3CO* and subsequently methanol, or it can dissociate into CHx intermediates for further CO insertion to produce alcohols[14]. The stronger HCOO* peak intensity on Rh/FCMA-LDO suggests a higher likelihood of syngas conversion to alcohols. Additionally, absorption peaks at 2963, 2933, 2851 and 1100 cm−1 are observed on both catalysts, indicative of the H3CO* intermediate. The more pronounced H3CO* peak on FCMA-LDO implies a higher tendency to generate methanol, while Rh/FCMA-LDO favors the production of C2+OH, consistent with the observed alcohol distribution in the experimental results. 4 Conclusions To efficiently synthesize alcohols from syngas, a series of supported FeCu-based catalysts were developed and evaluated for their catalytic performance. Utilizing FeCu/LDH as precursors was found to enhance the ordering and dispersion of FeCu alloys within the catalyst structure. Modification of the FeCu LDO catalyst with Pd, Pt or Rh significantly improved the catalytic activity by promoting CO adsorption and dissociation while suppressing non-dissociative CO adsorption. Addition of Pd and Rh increases the number of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, but addition of Pt lowers the oxygen vacancy content in the catalyst. This modification facilitated the formation of HCOO* and CHx intermediates, thereby enhancing CO conversion and alcohol production. Among the modified catalysts, the Rh-promoted FeCu-LDO catalyst exhibited the best performance, because the incorporation of Rh not only intensifies the synergistic interaction between FeCu active sites but also stabilizes the catalyst layered architecture, thereby modulating its basicity and significantly enhancing its catalytic performance. Rh/FCMA-LDO yielded a remarkably high alcohol selectivity of 95.1 %, while only 1.34 % CO2 and 1.67 % methane selectivity were achieved from this study. These results demonstrate the great potential of Rh-modified FeCu/LDH based catalysts as highly efficient systems for alcohol synthesis from syngas. coredata.dc:description: A highly dispersed FeCu/LDH-based catalyst precursor was prepared by co-precipitation method, and the catalysts promoted with Pd, Pt or Rh were then prepared using an equal-volume impregnation method to be used in syngas-to-alcohol reaction. These samples were characterized by XRD, Raman, FT-IR, In-situ DRIFT, XPS, SEM and N2 adsorption desorption. The study reveals that the 2D nanosheet structure of the LDH precursor has a large surface area and evenly distributed active sites, leading to the superior catalyst performance. The promoted catalyst generated even higher catalytic activity and alcohol selectivity, notably reducing undesired methane and CO2 by-products. Rh incorporation obviously enhanced the thermal stability of the catalyst, leading to the long-term retention of the LDH structure. Rich -OH groups offer surface basicity, thereby significantly enhancing its catalytic performance to lower the CO2 selectivity to 1.34 % and methane to 1.67 % while achieving a remarkable alcohol selectivity of 95.1 %. In-situ DRIFT results reveal that Rh promotion helps balance the gaseous adsorption and bridge adsorption of CO for improved overall syngas-to-alcohols reaction results.
